Authors: Lingli He, Man Zhao, Yan Wang, Junyi Gai, Chaoying He
Title:
Genome-wide characterizations with a focus on soybean reveal
that the evolution of the PHO1 gene family is associated with the origin
of diversification of land plants
Keywords:
evolution, gene expression, PHO1 gene family, phylogeny,
soybean
Abstract:
The PHO1 genes originated in the ancestor of eukaryotes,
and became uniquely expanded in land plants with a varied copy number
ranging from 2 to 23, and they could be classified into two major groups
(Class I and Class II). Multiple gene duplication events appeared to
contribute to their expansion in land plants. The Class I genes are
particularly expanded in dicotyledonous plants and not found in
monocots, while the Class II genes cover all land plants and its copy
number is little changed. The absence of monocot sequences in Class I
may be attributed to gene losses after a duplication event in the
ancestor of the seed plants. Their intron number varies from 7 to 14,
and since ancestral state reconstruction analyses revealed that the
genes with 13 introns are ancestors, therefore, the intron loss is
largely involved in the structural evolution of PHO1 genes. In the
soybean genome, 14 PHO1-like genes (GmaPHO1) were predicted; however,
only 12 are detectable at the mRNA level. These genes display
tissue-specific or tissue-preferential expression patterns during
soybean plant and fruit development. The genes belonging to Class I have
a broader expression pattern than those in Class II. GmaPHO1 genes
exhibit differentially altered expression levels in response to salt or
osmotic stresses, whereas almost none of the genes responds to Pi
deficient or sufficient stresses.
